title: 107_hr4141
content: The Act is titled the "Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002". Definitions include the Corporation, Red Rock, Red Rock Map, and Secretary. The purpose of the Act is outlined in Section 3. The Congress finds Red Rock as a significant natural resource that must be protected and enhanced for future generations. The Corporation owns land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and is developing a master-planned community, including 1,071 acres of high-ground lands that should be preserved to maintain the view-shed of the western Las Vegas Valley. The Corporation owns high-ground lands at the eastern edge of Red Rock, intended for inclusion in Red Rock but not yet acquired by the United States. They propose the US acquire the lands to preserve the view-shed of the western Las Vegas Valley. The Act aims to exchange lands between the US and the Corporation to protect and expand Red Rock as outlined by the Bureau of Land Management. The Corporation aims to protect and expand Red Rock by exchanging lands with the US as outlined by the Bureau of Land Management and to fulfill the purposes of relevant acts. The Corporation aims to protect and expand Red Rock by exchanging lands with the US as outlined by the Bureau of Land Management and relevant acts, including SEC. 4. RED ROCK LAND EXCHANGE. The Corporation offers to convey approximately 1,082 acres of nonfederal land to the United States for incorporation into the NCA. In exchange, the Corporation will receive approximately 998 acres of Federal lands, and Clark County, Nevada will receive approximately 1,221 acres of Federal lands for a park. The conveyances of private and Federal property will occur simultaneously. The Red Rock Map will be kept on file for public inspection in the Las Vegas District Office of the Bureau of Land Management in Nevada. The Secretary will keep the Red Rock Map on file for public inspection in Nevada. Conditions for conveyance include hazardous materials removal and a survey of the common boundary. The Secretary will require a metes and bounds survey of the common boundary between parcels to be conveyed to Clark County. Lands transferred must be used as a public park or part of a regional trail system, with reversion to the United States if not preserved. SEC. 5. STATUS AND MANAGEMENT OF LANDS. Upon enactment of this Act, the Secretary will administer the Flood Control Detention Basin Lands depicted on the Red Rock Map as part of Red Rock, excluding those used for the Corps of Engineers R-4 Detention Basin. Acquired lands will also be administered as part of Red Rock, with new maps reflecting boundary adjustments available for review at the Las Vegas District Office. The Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area will be modified according to the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002. New maps will show the updated boundaries, available for review at the Bureau of Land Management offices in Las Vegas and Reno, Nevada. The Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area will be modified as per the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002. New maps with updated boundaries will be available for review at Bureau of Land Management offices in Las Vegas and Reno, Nevada. General provisions are outlined in Section 6. The Secretary will review the appraisal for the Red Rock Exchange in Las Vegas and any difference in values will be reimbursed. The land exchange will respect valid existing rights, and parties will succeed to rights and obligations. Technical corrections to the Red Rock Map are allowed. The Secretary will withdraw affected lands from public land and mining laws, subject to valid existing rights. The Secretary will withdraw Federal lands acquired or owned by the United States under the Act from public land and mining laws, subject to valid existing rights. Technical errors in the Red Rock Map can be corrected by agreement of the parties involved. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 1, 2002.
